text: It's seven o'clock and the birds are singing in the trees outside an old, two-story frame house with a sagging fron porch and peeling white paint, anly half-covered by a par paint job. MRS, NOONAN (v.0.) (shouting cheerily) Let's go kids! Rise and shine! Let's hit the deck! Let's go-go-go! A dog begins BARKING.
Doors fly open and a half dozen children start pouring in the hall, racing for the bathroom, and rough~-housing dow the stairs.
She stands at the foot of the stairs calling up to the ga of kids. She's a plump, cheerful woman with a helpful, supportive manner. The family COLLIE runs up the stairs still BARKING.
{calling out) Up, up, up! Andy? Billy? I'm not hearing any movement up there! Make sure Danny's up, please, Uppie- uppie everybody!

The first light of day filters through the window reveali an incredibly messy boy's bedroom littered with dirty lau books, comics, breken toys and an electric guitar. The wa are covered with KISS posters, framed athletic awards and cheesy trophies on a homemade bookshelf, Little League te pictures and a poster-sized blow-up of John Belushi. A br model spaceship dangles from a thread from the ceiling fi

Three brothers share the room. ANDY and BILLY, twelve and thirteen are getting dressed. DANNY NOONAN, age eighteen, sits on the cdge of his bed rubbing his eyes. He's a manl good-looking, athletic kid with a kind of quick, natural intelligence -- the oldest and biggest of the Noonan kids
(shouts) I'm up. He hops out of bed and heads for the bathroom.
BILLY, ED and KATHLEEN are already lined up at the bathro door, waiting impatiently in their pajamas.
(impatiently) Who's in there?
Danny, will you tell Nancy to get out of there?
She's been in there an hour! Danny goes right to the bathroom door, knocks once and ba catching twelve year old NANCY in her panties, her mother rouge and lipstick smeared on her mouth.
Come on, Nance!
{screams) Danny! She grabs her robe and runs out.
(off camera) Mother! Danny saw me naked!
There's not much to see. Danny puts some Crest on his toothbrush and leaves the bathroom.
As Danny comes out; Billy, Ed and Kathleen fight to get i next.
I'm next! I called it!
(pushing him) Oh no you don't!
Shotgun! Danny heads back to his bedroom and almost trips over a t year old sitting on a potty.
I'm pooping, Danny.
(laughs) I'm proud.

MR. NOONAN, Danny's father, is trying to eat breakfast an read the newspaper while the kids pop in and out of the room. He loves his children, but over the years, with eac new addition to the family, he's come to feel more and mo - like a forgotten guest in his own home. Danny comes through the dining room on his way to the kit
Hi, Dad. Can I ---
No.
(protesting) You didn't even hear ---
Whatever it is -- no! Danny goes through the open door into the kitchen unfazed his father's churlishness.

MRS. NOONAN is busy making fried egg sandwiches. A crying four year old clings to her apron while other kids pillag the refrigerator, spill milk and orange juice, and slop cereal into bowls. The dog is barking, the phone is ringi and the radio plays loudly. Danny gets a bowl and spoon f the cupboard.
-- aS soon as you guys get back from Little League, maybe we can get some painting done on the house. Thirteen year old SAM runs in and grabs a sandwich.
The Douglases got fake brick. You don't have to paint it.
Hooray for the Douglases. A baby in a high chair throws a cup.
Dory! Bad girl! (to the crying four year old) Sally, honey, you don't have to be up yet. Go back to bed. Danny grabs the Cheerios and is almost out the door.
Danny? No word from St. Copius yet?
(evasive) No, but I'm not so sure about that place anymore. I talked to a guy who went to college there. It's right in the middle of a cornfield. They get eight feet of snow ---
It's a fine college and you know it.
I don't know anything, He escapes to the dining room, and without sitting down, the pitcher of milk off the table and pours some on his ‘
You get out yesterday?
_ (spooning lots of sugar on his cereal} Twice. I caddied for Mr. Webb in the morning and then doubles in the afternoon.
How much is that?
Twelve-sixty plus about three bucks in tips.

Well? Put it in the college fund. Danny sighs, puts down his bowl and goes to a kitchen cup digging into his pocket. Mr. Noonan watches him through t open door. Mrs. Noonan is wiping up spills and feeding th dog at the same time.
Maybe you should call the St. Copius scholarship people. They should've let you know by now. Sally, honey, don't put eggs in your hair.
(pulling bills out of his pocket) I heard there's only two girls there and they're both nuns. This guy had to take a cow to the prom and the cow had to be in carly.
Well, the Mazenak boy went to St. Copious and he had a marvelous time.
{taking a cookie jar off the shelf} Me's the one who went out with the cow. He stuffs the money into the cookie jar trying to hide it from his father.
(from the dining room) I saw that! That was about five bucks and change. Danny comes back into the dining room eating his cereal.
I had a couple of burgers and some Pepsis for lunch. He flees toward the kitchen.
How many Pepsis?
(from the kitchen} Four or five.
What are you -- a diabetic!?
Hit him, Dad! Get the strap! Danny's a diatetic! Danny dumps his dirty dishes in the sink.
(shouts from the dining room) You're not leaving this house till we settle this college thing.
I'm just going upstairs for a minute. He dashes out of the kitchen and up the stairs.
(o.s. to Mrs. Noonan) I'm telling you, if he hasn't got anything lined up by September, I'm going to ask Tom Burdick to put him on at the lumberyard.

He can hear his parents arguing as he rummages in his clo MRS. NOONAN (0.s.)} He's not going to work in the lumber- yard! Danny grabs a faded windbreaker and a letter drops out of pocket. He reads it with a grim expression.
It reads: The St. Copius scholarship foundation regrets t inform you that your application for student aid has been refused, etc.
MR. NOONAN (0.s.) Well, he's not going to be a caddy all his life, is he?
He folds up the letter and hides it on a shelf. MRS. NOONAN (v.0.) Danny? Devilled ham or tuna? JI can't open both.
{shouts} How about neither? With the argument continuing downstairs, he goes to the window and jumps out. For a moment we think he's committe suicide.
He swings nimbly to a downspout, hops to a tree branch, climbs through a weathered treehouse and slides down a rope to the ground. Then he jumps on a Sears ten speed bike and pedals away.
Danny rides down a street lined with houses like his own.
The houses are bigger, the lawns wider and greener, as Danny crosses over into a more exclusive section of the suburbs.
Now Danny is riding past large mansions on rambling estat
Danny turns down a private driveway flanked by two stone columns. On one column is a brass plaque that reads: Bushwood Country Club. END CREDITS.

Early morning mist rises from the golf course and shafts sunlight slant through the trees as we look at two figure standing on the tee five hundred yards away. One of the figures swings, a click is heard and ball sails into the air. It hangs for a long moment and drops right in the middle of the fairway, two hundred yards from the green. The golfer hands his club to his caddy and starts walking toward the ball. As they approach, we begin to see them more clearly. It i Danny, caddying for TY WEBB, a handsome, thirty-ish bache with clear eyes and an air of relaxed self control. His outfit is all soft flannel and cashmere. Everything about him tells us that he is the perfect golfer.
They walk along in quiet conversation. Danny tries hard t match Ty's easy, elegant stride.
Mr. Webb, can I ask you something?
Sure.
When you were eighteen, do you remember having trouble deciding what you wanted to do with your... uh, you know...life?
Sure. I didn't know whether to go to West Point, sail my father's ship to the islands or just take a year off skiing in the Alps. why?

Forget it. I don't think you'd understand. Ty Come on. I know what you mean. I had the same problem at eighteen, at twenty-one, twenty-five, twenty-nine and thirty-two ~~ and yesterday. I almost blew my brains out with a silver-plated Beretta. So what's your problem?
What isn't my problem? Did you have to take the Cooter Preference test when you were a senior in high school?
Yes. It said I should be a firewatcher. What are you supposed to be?
An underachiever. {shakes his head) I gotta go to college. I gotta!
Do you want to go to college?

In Nebraska? Besides, it costs like eight thousand dollars a year. My Dad can't afford it. And I haven't even told him about the scholarship I didn't get. I'll probably have to work in a lumberyard for the rest of my life.
What's wrong with lumber. I own two lumberyards.
I notice you don't spend too much time there.
I don't know where they are. They reach Ty's ball.
Ty's ball rests near the edge of a beautiful lake that cuts across the fairway. On the opposite shore is a lovely green flanked by sandtraps.
Okay, Danny. TI think you've suffered enough. First lesson. Did you sce Star Wars? (he takes a silk scarf out of his golf bag) LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh Anum  10
Yeah --~
All right. I'll be Alec Guiness and you be the wimpy kid from the Space farm.
Thanks.

(blindfolding himself) There's a force in the universe that makes things happen. Al1 you have to do is get in touch with it. He fumbles with the clubs in his bag, feeling for a seven iron. Finally he lifts the blindfold a little and takes the right club. Then he goes to his ball and takes a blindfolded practice swing.
Find your center -~- stop thinking -- let it happen -- ‘Be the ball' -- (he swings and hits the ball)
It sails over the lake, hits high on the green and rolls down to within inches of the hole.
Danny stands there amazed. Ty starts blindfolding him.
(surprised) What?
Hit one. Try it. Danny peeks to line up the shot, then lowers the blindfol and gets ready to hit.
ir
(droning hypnotically) Just relax -- be the ball -- find your center -- turn off all the sound -- picture the shot -- be completely still: --~
(impatiently) It's a little hard with you talking like that.
Oh! All right -- I'1l shut up -- I'm shutting up now -- I've stepped talking. Danny swings and hits the ball. Ty watches it rise and drop into the lake.
{taking off the blindfold} Where'd it go?
Right in the lumberyard. We'll work on it -- honestly. Just figure out what you really want. Once you know, everything else takes care of itself. They walk off together. A mechanical roar is heard.

A huge grasscutter appears suddenly over a rise, it's big plaid blower bags ballooning out from its sides. The GROUNDSKEEPER waves casually to Ty and Danny from his tractor seat as he rumbles past them. cuT TO

A public transit bus stops across the street from the: ma entrance to the club. The route sign on the front of ‘the bus reads: FROM THE ClTY. The bus pulls away revealing a half dozen teenage CADDIES arriving for work. They cross the street, rollicking and punching at each other. A few Black and Latin Maids and Kitchen Helpers arrive with the

The caddies come up the driveway. Leading the group is TONY D'ANNUNZIO, nineteen, a tough-looking, inner-city kid with disco haircut and a cigarette dangling negligent from his lips. With him are his brothers -~ ANGIE, a mild-mannered, dopily smiling seventeen year old and JOEY, fourteen, Bushwood's newest caddy, tough like Tony, but cuter.
He accosts one of the maids.

Hey, Maria! The Immigration guy was lookin’ for you yesterday. You know, there's a law if you screw an Italian, you're an automatic citizen. She laughs uncomprehendingly and continues talking in Spanish to her friends, Two other caddies have arrived with the D'’Annunzio’s -- GOOFY, a gawky, bespectacled sixteen year old and MOTORMOUTH, a fast-talking, eighteen year old class clown As they cut across the parking lot, they check out the ca of the club members.

{like an announcer) We're here at the Thirteenth Annual Bushwood Auto Show and what a collection of four-wheel fantasies we have here, right Goofy? (raps a stationwagon) ~- Here's a newcomer to this morning's show, Mr. and Mrs. Newburger's 1981 Ford Country Square.
Breathtakingly beautiful.
An absolute hog.
A black Porsche Turbo Carrera with prominent "MD" marking races up the access road toward the parking lot. The driv has to slam on his brakes to avoid hitting the D'Annunzio

who are deliberately slow getting out of the way. The horn honks frantically. The caddies slowly clear the road as the driver guns his motor. The moment they're clear, he lurches forward to pass them.
He does a flip off the car as if he's been hit and lands sprawled on the grass.
{rolling around in mock agony) Yaaaaaaaaaah!
It screeches to a halt. The tinted window WHIRS down revealing DR. BLAINE BEEPER, a rich, conceited big-city surgeon. He looks back, shocked.
Oh my God!
He's on the grass twitching and flopping, the other caddies standing around in horror.
Beeper grabs his black doctor's bag and leaps from the ca He stops.
Both Joey and the caddies have disappeared.
He slams his doctor's bag against a tree trunk in a rage then looks at it realizing what he's done. He gives the b a tentative shake and hears a $6,000 tinkle of broken gla and instruments.

Several caddies are lounging in the yard in front of the caddyshack -- a one-story white frame building with green tile roof and green shutters. Joey DB'Annunzio practices hook shots against a backboard attached to the wall.

He's sitting on a bench with RAY, an old, professional ca wearing a dirty golf cap with an emblem from the 1946 Bui Open. His suntanned arms are covered with tatoos. Goffy dunks doughnuts into his coffee as Ray talks.
I jumped ship in Hong Kong and Inade my way to Tibet where I got on as a looper at this golf club up there in the Himalayan Mountains.
A looper?

A caddie -- a jock! So I tell ‘em I'm a pro, so who do they give me? The Dalai Lama himself ~- flowin' white robes and everything. So I give him his driver and he tees off -- right into this glacier and his ball goes down this 10,000 foot crevice. And you know what the Dalai Lama says?
No.
‘shit.’ Yeah -- 'Shit!' And you know what else. I'm full of shit. Yeah. ~~ Goofy stares at him with his mouth full of doughnut.
He crosses the caddyyard. From the way the caddies greet him, we can see that he's both liked and respected. A basketball rolls up to him.
(shouts) Hey, Noonan! Little help! Danny picks up the ball, closes his eyes and takes a hook shot at the basket.
The ball sails high over the backboard and onto the roof of the caddyshack.
He glares at Danny.
Thanks a lot, wipehole! Danny goes into the caddyshack.
More caddies are lounging on benches, playing cards, etc. Danny enters and goes to the window of the caddymaster's office. Tony D'’Annunzio is in the office.
(holding up a ticket) Hiya, Tony. Where's Lou?
He went to the Pro Shop for a minute, You wanna take over till he gets back?
Where you goin'? Angie, Tony's rat-like brother, appears.
Noonan, you wanna buy some clock radios?
Nah ---
Got any friends who want clock radios? .
How many you got?
How many you need? Angie walks away laughing.

INJUN JOE, a big silent Indian of indeterminate age is pl a game with FEEB, a twitching adult caddy with just a hin mental deficiency. They take turns bowling at wooden tees a golf ball, betting on each roll.
(to Injun Joe) Do you have a dime for ten pennies?
{making fun of him) Hey, Feeb! What do you want a dime for when you got ten pennies? Ten is more than one.
Pennies only work in the gumball machine. I want M & M's.
(joining Angie) Here, Feeb. I'11 give it to you. Feeb holds out the pennies to Joey who slaps his hand, scattering them all over the caddyshack.
He turns to look and sees the little D'Annunzio's botheri Feeb.
{to Tony) Your brothers are animals. (shouts at them) cut it out, moron!
He's on his knees looking for his pennies.
Here, Feeb. Here’s a dime.
Thank you, Injun Joe. He gets off his knees, but Angie snatches his cap and tos it to Joey.
(calls plaintively) Dan -- ny -- They got my hat again.
(steps in) Give it back to him, Joey.
Here. (he tosses it back to his brother} Angie! Danny turns to Angie.

You want it, Noonan? Take it. Danny grabs for him but Joey jumps on his back and they g knocking over a gumball machine which breaks and sends gu rolling all over the place. Then Angie jumps on Danny to Joey, but Tony arrives and yanks Angie to his feet, cuffi sharply a couple of times. Danny gets a good grip on Litt Joey's neck and pastes him to the wall. Younger caddies scurry around after the pennies and gumba Injun Joe laughs.

LOU LOOMIS, the Caddymaster, enters. He's a likable maste sergeant type with a veneer of toughness to keep the cadd in line. Lou (over the noise) Okay, break it up! Pipe down! All of you! Angie takes on last wild swing at Danny but accidentally Lou on the arm. The caddies go suddenly quiet. Lou grabs and pushes him over to a sign on the wall.
What™s the sign say?
No fighting.
What's it mean?
No fighting.

You owe me one gumball machine. Now clean up that mess, (Angie starts to protest) Now! {turning to Danny and Tony) What is this? I count on you guys to keep these monkeys in line. (squinting at Joey) What's that candy wrapper doing there? (Joey looks down) Don't you see it? Well, pick it up! Joey picks it up. Lou addresses all the caddies.

{turning to cowed caddics) Now, I'm not going to have any trouble from you guys this summer-. I'll put it right on the line -- there's been a lot of complaints already -- fooling around on the course. Bad language. Smoking grass. Poor caddying. (the caddies hang their heads in mock shame) So if you want to get fired, just keep it up. Somebody belches. Lou turns to Jocy, hands him a kleenex for his blecdy nose.

And another thing. If any of you are thinking of going to college-- Noonan, you may want to listen to this -- Carl Lipbaum died last week in summer school from a severe anxiety attack. The caddies mutter in surprise and sympathy.
I heard he swallowed his vomit during a test.
LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh  19
However it happened, he was a good eaddy and a good kid.
He was a brown nose, Lou. You hated him.
Anyway, that means the caddy scholar- ship is available -- and anyone who wants it should go see Judge Smails.
And kiss his ass.
That would help. Now let's go. We got golfers waiting. The caddies start to file out the door.
You, Joey! Pick up that blcod.

A cloud of steam billows from the steam room as the door opens. Several portly members can be seen through the mis They lock like ancient Roman senators wrapped in their sh and towels. Several other members stand or sit around the locker room, playing cards or changing in and out of golf and tennis togs.
A rich old fart and presiding head of Bushwood holds out pair of golf shoes to SMOKE, the black locker room attend

(irritably) Oh, Westinghouse! Look at the built-up wax on these shoes. This is quality leather. I want the wax stripped, and I want them creamed and buffed with a soft chamois, and I want them now. Chopchop. —
Yes, your Honor. Smoke applies one shoe to an electric buffer.

(on the phone) We're just about to tee off now so move all my appointments back a half hour. Testing now: (he unhooks an electronic beeper from his belt) Three, two, one, test. (his beeper goes off) Check.
He's now in the middle of a joke.
(bad Jewish accent) »..and then we eat and eat, and screw and screw until we drop from exhaustion. lUvery day! A fat OLD CRONY begins to giggle.
{continuing} »+-and Solly says, ‘Moe! Moc! Heaven sounds wonderful! and the other Jewish fellow says ---
He's sitting behind another row of lockers listening to t joke as he ties his shoes, SMAILS {v.0.) Heaven? What do you mean heaven?
He rises to the punchline, but Ty beats him to it. TY (v.o.) (shouts, interrupting) -+-I'm a bull in Montana! Smails winces and looks sharply at Ty, who appears from the lockers.
His pudgy The CRONY pink face jiggles as he laughs.
You have to hang it to the Jews -- they know how funny they are.
You're not suggesting we change our membership policy. puts on a Bishop's collar and closes his locker.
Oh, no. They have many fine clubs of their own.
(icily) Oh, hello Webb. What'd you shoot today?
I don't keep score, your Honor. Ty heads for the exit and stops, blocked by Beeper's stretched-out phone cord.
Beep-beep. Beeper jumps and Ty exits.

(shakes head contemptucusly) That fellow's got a real chip on his shoulder too bad for his father. (changing mood) Say, Bishop, did you hear the one about the little colored boy who --- He frowns and presses the Judge's golf shoe against the buffing wheel until the shoe begins to smoke and sparks shoot out. Then he looks at the shoc and smiles at the big burned patch on the toe.
The caddies troop up. the path to the first tee area.
MOTORMOUTH (v.o0.) Well, it’s a lovely day for looping here at the beautiful Bushwood Country Club.
He holds a candy bar like a hand mike. Goofy and Danny walk alongside.

We've got about twenty-five loopers all primed and ready to be assigned their prospective loops by Looper Leader Lou Loomis. And gee, they're an excited bunch of caddies -- all pumped up to hump those fifty pound bags about five miles. Right, Danny?
That's right, Mouth. It's a grueling test of strength and ignorance.

Danny approaches the practice tee and sees SAM RIVIERA, t club's golf pro, finishing a lesson with MR. & MRS. HAVER Sam is about forty, deeply tanned and dressed in pastel g sweater and slacks. The Havercamps are a cheerfully senil old couple, dressed in matching outfits, who keep gamely trying to hit their practice shots. They succeed only in gouging deep holes around their golf balls as they repeat swing and miss.
He watches with weary patience as the Havercamps ineptly away.
Okay, Mr. Havercamp, try looking . at the ball this time. Mrs. Havercamp, you've got your clubface turned around again. The old man swings and gouges a huge divot.
(she giggles, swings and hits a short dribbler) Whee!
Danny picks up their matching baby-blue golf bags and app the Havercamps.
Morning, Mr. Havercamp, Mrs. Havercamp. I'm Danny. You're next up.
Let's go, Dolly. I'm hot today.
MRS. HAVERCAMP is about to drive.
(winding up) Ready for blast-off! Whee! She tops the ball and it rolls thirty feet down the fairw
(applauding) That was a peach, hon!
He stands next to Danny watching Mr. Havercamp.
(shouting encouragement) Excellent! (to Danny) Good luck, Noonan. This could be the longest eighteen holes ever played.
Several tables are filled with members having sandwiches and beer.

MAGGIE, a very cute, rosy~checked Irish girl in her early twenties. When her last customer exits, she turns to the frozen custard machine, takes the bigger size sugar cone and dispenses for hersclf an incredibly tall, very precar Softee Freeze. She takes a happy lick and spots Danny com off the ninth,
He trudges up to the Snack Shop completely exhausted, his shirt soaked with sweat. Maggie smiles and signals covert to him. Danny slips around to the back of the Snack Shop.
Maggie comes out and gives him a free burger and a shake.
Hi, Maggic.
Hi. Don't let the Judge see you. (Danny tries to steal a kiss but she ducks it) Not here. (she hands him a pair of boys underpants) You left these last night when you ran off.
(embraces her) I had to babysit. You want to go out again tonight?
Out to my room? Look, Danny, I like you a lot, but let's not make a regular thing out of it. We've got a good friendship going and I'd like to keep it that way. Besides, I got some bad news today.
(nibbles her ear} What?
{hugs him tightly) They won't renew my work permit. I have to go back to Ireland at the end of the summer.
(sincerely) Gee, that's a drag, Mag.
LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh  25
I really want to stay. (hinting cheerfully) If I were married to an American, I could.
{laughs) No problem. You could live in my roam ~- under the bed.
Aren't you going to college?
Doesn't look like it -- unless I get the caddy scholarship.
You'll get it. {teasing} And we'll get married -~ just for show, of course -- and I'll be a stewardess for Aer Lingus and be flyin' all over the place. Now doesn't that sound like something?
He comes around the corner of the Snack Shop.
Aer Lingus? I know her sister -- Connie.
(laughing) You've got a smart mouth.
That's what Connie told me. Danny sees Mr. Havercamp looking around for him.
{rushing off) I gotta go!
{calls out) Come by later!
Hey, Maggie. The Immigration guy was lookin' for you yesterday ---
SANDY MacFIDDISH, Bushwood's Scottish greenskecpcr, is standing by his electric utility cart with his tartan tam in his hands, taking orders from Judge Smails.
(irate) Do you know what moles can do to a golf course?
They must be tunnclin’ in from that construction site across the road.
I don't care where they're coming from. JI want every last mole extermianted or Bushwood will start looking for a new greens- keeper. Is that clear?
Very clear, sir.
It pops its head out of a hole and cocks its head. Then i hears a noise and ducks back in.
He drags a thick water hose onto the fairway and sticks t nozzle into the mole hole.
Danny comes off the course really exhausted now, followed by the Havercamps, indomitable despite having played the worst round of golf imaginable.
(handing them their scorecards) I get 188 for you, sir, and 202 for your wife.
Hold on a minute, son. I get 186 for me. Well, let's not make a ~ federal case out of it. This is for you -- and thanks. (hands him a tip) LINOUNTALLIGE. CGh  27
holding two shiny quarters. DANNY (v.0.) (disappointed) Thank you, sir.

He trots wearily across a fairway lugging both golf bags. He trips over Sandy's water hose and falls flat on his fa The clubs spill out of the bags with a noisy clatter and two dozen golf balls go rolling off in all directions.
(totally exasperated) God damn son of a bitch! His anger is cut short as he spots someone walking toward

Danny sees LACEY UNDERALL, a very beautiful girl, walking toward him in a short, very alluring tennis skirt. She has slim, shapely legs, long, golden hair, a great tan an a cover-girl complexion. She's carrying a tennis racquet and with one smooth move, she benés slightly and scoops up one of the golf balls that rolled away from Danny.
{tossing the golf ball to Danny) Walk much?

(stuffing the clubs back into the bags) Oh, no. I just -- I was just resting. She smiles and walks away with a toss of her curls. Her walk is both sexy and athletic. She absently brushes a fly off the back of her thigh with her racquet.
He gapes at her and suddenly water comes shooting up out a dozen moleholes, falling like rain on Danny.
fhey stand looking up at the sky, getting completely dren

The tennis courts are hidden behind dense bushes but the pock~pock of balls being hit can be heard as Danny saunte by. He nods casually to a pair of golfers as they pass, then as soon as they're gone, Danny ducks into the bushes
We can hear the sound of youthful laughter as Danny peers through the hurricane fence at the tennis courts.

Lacey is playing with three young club MEMBERS. Her partn is SPAULDING SMAILS, a pudgy, truculent-looking seventeen old -- Judge Smails' spoiled grandson. Lacey hits a nice backhand, then waits for there turn, bu Spaulding insists on taking the next shot.
I got it! It's mine! Lacey backs off relucantly and watches Spaulding hit a lame forehand right into the net.
Shit! (blaming Lacey) Will you stay out of my way! He flings his racquet in disgust.
Christ, Spaulding! I hope you screw better than you play tennis.
NOBLE NOYES, a tomboyish girl with fuzzy red hair walks u to the net.
Hey, Lacey, are you coming to the dinner dance tonight?
Will it be any good?
No.
(walking back to the base line to serve) You talked me into it.

The TENNIS PRO, a middle-aged, red-faced man wearing whit and a floppy tennis hat, walks by and sees Danny's ass sticking out of the bushes. Ue puts down the basket of practice balls he's carrying, winds up to swing with his racquet, and swats Danny hard on the backside. INT’. CLUB KITCHEN Danny comes flying through the door into a maelstrom of activity. It's all banging pots, and sizzling stoves with food and people flying everywhere. He's in a white jacket carrying a big tray of dirty dishes.
CHARLIE, the Hungarian cook is screaming at everyone as h carves a big roast with a huge butcher knife.
(pounding the knife) This! This! (chops a sponge in half) That! That! (waves his arms and the knife goes flying out of his hand)
The huge knife sticks in the wall just in front of his fa He drops two racks full of glasses.
She snags Danny and pulls him through the swinging doors.
Danny and Maggie bustle over to a service area and start loading trays with ice water, rolls and butter. Danny locks around the room and spots Lacey.

The Chevy wagon speeds down the street. Andy whips papers out of the open tailgate.
